subject: RE: [junit] Running time consuming JUnit Tests
msgSnippet: ... I always thought the solution was that you maintained a list of tests NOT to run. This list may vary by platform (some tests don t work on platform X
messageBody:
> Another question: how would you handle a test that is supposed to pass but that
> currently fails because of a problem you can't fix? "All the tests must pass
> all the time" is fine if you have control over the entire code, but what if one
> of the libraries you use has a bug? While other are fixing the library, your
> tests are still broken but it's still ok to commit new code (because no other
> new test fail)...

I always thought the solution was that you maintained a list of tests NOT
to run. This list may vary by platform (some tests don't work on platform X
because it doesn't support threading, or whatever), and it may change over
time (as a bug in a library is discovered, then later fixed). The list itself
is clear documentation. The only trick is getting junit to not run the tests
on the list... depends on how you run your tests. (Eg: a master suite class
that collects together all the tests, or an ant task that lists them...
whatever it is, enhance it to respect your SKIPPED_TESTS list.)

-- Michael Chermside
